newsitem.title: FRANCE: China says to clear Shell petchem project.
newsitem.headline: China says to clear Shell petchem project.

text.p: China on Friday pledged its long awaited approval for plans to build a major petrochemical plant in its Guandong province in co-operation with Anglo-Dutch oil giant Royal Dutch/Shell.
China's executive vice chairman of state planning, Ye Qing, told reporters in Paris he expected Chinese authorities soon to approve the plan.

"I saw the managing director of Shell two days ago and I told him that I personally and the state commission will approve this project very soon," Ye told a news conference after meeting Western energy ministers during a break in oil consumer talks.
A spokesman for Shell in London declined to comment.
Ye said the plant, to be built at Huizhou in the booming Guandong region of southern China, was expected to produce 850,000 tonnes a year of ethylene.
This had been raised from previous plans for 450,000 tonnes of annual capacity. Ethylene is used for making plastic.
The project is a joint venture with the China National Offshore Oil Corporation. Shell holds a 50 percent stake.

It is, however, a scaled-down version of a plan originally valued at $6 billion that was to have included an oil refinery as well as a petrochemical plant. China unexpectedly dropped its support for the 160,000 barrel a day refinery early this year.
Ye did not say how much the ethylene plant alone was worth.
He made clear, however, that plans for a refinery at the same site remained on hold.
"To ensure a better return for the project we have decided not to build a refinery at the same time but to import" oil products to supply the petrochemical complex, he said.

China's apparent backing for the petrochemical plant will be seen as a partial victory for Shell after years of complex negotiations, but leaves doubts over China's unpredictable policy towards foreign oil refinery projects, analysts said.
On the drawing board currently are South Korea's Yukong Ltd 120,000 bpd refinery plan in Shenzhen and Saudi Aramco's 200,000-bpd refinery in Qingdao.
In January, China said Beijing would look at proposals for refineries from foreign companies on a case-by-case basis and did not rule out clearing new projects.

But in the same month, it told senior officials from Mobil Corp of the United States that it was not encouraging moves to build joint-venture refineries and would rather expand domestic refineries on its own.

Chinese sources said in February that overcapacity of the country's refinery sector was a worry for state planners, with plants running at only around 70 percent. Poor profit margins for refiners were another reason for freezing out foreign firms.
China's only joint venture refinery with foreign interest is the Dalian West Pacific Petrochemical Corp where Total of France holds a 20 percent stake.
A planned 120,000 bpd refining project in Shanghai with France's Elf fell through in 1995.
